data.title: Maximilian Schell
data.meta_description: Handsome, charismatic and with an aristocratic bearing, Maximilian Schell became one of the best known European actors in Hollywood after starting his career in classical theatre. His considerable
data.text:
Handsome, charismatic and with an aristocratic bearing, Maximilian Schell became one of the best known European actors in Hollywood after starting his career in classical theatre. His considerable attributes — bringing weight and gravitas to any role — culminated in him winning the best actor Oscar for 1961. Schell beat Spencer Tracy and Paul Newman for his performance as the impassioned German lawyer Hans Rolfe in Judgment at Nuremberg.

Directed by Stanley Kramer, Judgment at Nuremberg dramatised the postwar trials of four German judges. When he reprised the role of Rolfe (he had first played the part in the 1959 American television production), Schell took a notably cerebral approach to the character and his complexities.
